tit.cmt: ハイフンをとりました。

sen.j: ウカノミタマは、日本神話に登場する神 (神道)。
sen.e: Ukano-mitama is a deity that appears in Japanese Mythology (Shinto religion).
Ukano-mitama is a deity that appears in Japanese Mythology (Shinto religion).
Ukanomitama is a deity that appears in Japanese Mythology (Shinto religion).
sen.cmt: ハイフンをとりました。

sen.j: 古事記では宇迦之御魂神（うかのみたまのかみ）、日本書紀では倉稲魂尊（うがのみたまのみこと）と表記する。
sen.e: Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters) describes it as "Ukanomitama-no-kami" and Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) as "Ugano-mitama-no-mikoto."
Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters) describes it as "Ukanomitama-no-kami" and Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) as "Ugano-mitama-no-mikoto."
Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters) describes it as "Ukanomitama no kami" and Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) as "Uganomitama no mikoto."
sen.cmt: ハイフンをとり、"Ukanomitama no kami","Uganomitama no mikoto"としました。

sen.j: 古事記では、スサノオの系譜において登場ひ、スサノオと神大市比売（オオヤマツミの娘）との間に生まれ、大年神は兄としている。
sen.e: In Kojiki, the pedigree record of Susano (Deity in Japanese Mythology) defines it as a child who was born between Susano and Kamu-oichi-hime (a daughter of Oyamatsumi) and a brother of Otoshi no kami.

In Kojiki, the pedigree record of Susano (Deity in Japanese Mythology) defines it as a child who was born between Susano and Kamu-oichi-hime (the daughter of Oyamatsumi) and a brother of Otoshi no kami.

In Kojiki, the pedigree record of Susanoo (Deity in Japanese Mythology) defines it as a child who was born between Susanoo and Kamu-oichi-hime (the daughter of Oyamatsumi) and a brother of Otoshi no kami.

sen.j: 日本書紀では本文には登場せず、神産みの第六の一書において、イザナギとイザナミが飢えて気力がないときに産まれたとしている。
sen.e: It does not appear in the main text of Nihonshoki but Arufumi of Section 6 describes that it was born when Izanagi (The Male Who Invites) and Izanami (The Female Who Invites) were starving and depressed.

It does not appear in the main text of Nihonshoki but Arufumi of Section 6 describes that it was born when Izanagi (The Male Who Invites) and Izanami (The Female Who Invites) were starving and depressed.

It does not appear in the main text of Nihonshoki but Arufumi (alternative variants to the main text) of Section 6, Kamiumi (the birth of deities) describes that it was born when Izanagi (The Male Who Invites) and Izanami (The Female Who Invites) were starving and depressed.
sen.cmt: Arufumi(一書)についてカッコ内で説明し、「神産み」の訳を加えました。

sen.j: 名前の「ウカ」は穀物・食物の意味で、穀物の神である。
sen.e: "Uka" in its name means grains and food, showing that it is a deity of harvest.
"Uka" in its name means grain and food, showing that it is a deity of harvest.
Uka' in its name means grain and food, showing that it is a deity of harvest.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更しました。

sen.j: 京都・伏見稲荷大社の主祭神になっていて、稲荷神（お稲荷さん）として広く信仰されている。
sen.e: It is the shusaijin (main enshrined deities) of Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine in Kyoto and widely worshiped as an Inari-shin (Oinari-san (god of harvests, wealth, fertility, etc.))
It is the shusaijin (main enshrined deities) of Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine in Kyoto and widely worshiped as an Inari-shin (Oinari-san - god of harvests, wealth, fertility, etc.)
It is the shusaijin (main enshrined deities) of Fushimi Inari-taisha Shrine in Kyoto and widely worshiped as an Inari-shin (Oinari-san - god of harvests, wealth, fertility, etc.)

sen.j: 別名をミケツカミ（御饌津神）という。
sen.e: It is also known as Miketsu Kami.
It is also known as Miketsu Kami.
It is also known as Miketsu Kami.

sen.j: キツネの古名である「ケツ」と混同し同一視されることがあるが、キツネの姿をしているのは稲荷神のお使いである。
sen.e: Some are confused to regard it as a fox because the fox was once called "Ketsu," but it is a messenger of the deity that assumes the shape of a fox..
Some are confused to regard it as a fox because the fox was once called "Ketsu," but it is a messenger of the deity that assumes the shape of a fox..
Some are confused to regard it as a fox because the fox was once called "Ketsu," but it is a messenger of the deity that assumes the shape of a fox.
sen.cmt: 余分なピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 古事記・日本書紀ともに名前が出て来るだけで事績の記述はない。
sen.e: Kojiki and Nihonshoki only mention its name without describing what it did.
Kojiki and Nihonshoki only mention its name without describing what it did.
Kojiki and Nihonshoki only mention its name without describing what it did.

sen.j: 性別がわかるような記述もなく、男神とも女神ともされる。
sen.e: The books do not describe its sex, so it is not clear whether it is a god or goddess
The books do not describe its sex, so it is not clear whether it is a god or goddess
The books do not describe its sex, so it is not clear whether it is a god or goddess

sen.j: 稲荷神社の総本社である伏見稲荷大社では女神としている。
sen.e: Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine, which is Grand Head shrine of Inari-jinja Shrine, regards it as a goddess.
Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine, which is the Grand Head shrine of Inari-jinja Shrine, regards it as a goddess.
Fushimi Inari-taisha Shrine, which is the grand head shrine of Inari-jinja Shrine, regards it as a goddess.
sen.cmt: Fushimi Inari-taisha Shrine, the grand head shrineとしました。

sen.j: 穀物の神としてだけでなく、農耕の神、商工業の神としても信仰されている。
sen.e: It is also worshiped as a deity of harvest as well as a deity of agriculture or a deity of commerce and industry.
It is also worshiped as a deity of harvest as well as a deity of agriculture or a deity of commerce and industry.
It is also worshiped as a deity of harvest as well as a deity of agriculture or a deity of commerce and industry.

sen.j: 伏見稲荷大社（京都市）、笠間稲荷神社（茨城県笠間市）、祐徳稲荷神社（佐賀県）などの全国の稲荷神社で祀られている。
sen.e: It is enshrined in Inari-jinja Shrines across the country such as Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine (Kyoto city), Kasamainari-jinja Shrine (Kasama City, Ibaraki Prefecture), Yutoku-inarijinjya Shrine (Saga Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is enshrined in Inari-jinja Shrines across the country such as Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine (Kyoto city), Kasamainari-jinja Shrine (Kasama City, Ibaraki Prefecture), Yutoku-inarijinjya Shrine (Saga Prefecture).

It is enshrined in Inari-jinja Shrines across the country such as Fushimi Inari-taisha Shrine (Kyoto city), Kasama Inari-jinja Shrine (Kasama City, Ibaraki Prefecture), Yutoku Inari-jinja Shrine (Saga Prefecture).
sen.cmt: Fushimi Inari-taisha Shrine, Kasama Inari-jinja Shrine, Yutoku Inari-jinja Shrineとしました。

sen.j: そのほか、ビルやデパートの屋上、工場の敷地内などにも、屋敷神として稲荷神を祀る社が設けられている。
sen.e: In addition, a small Shito shrine can be found on the roof of some buildings and department stores and in the precinct of some factories to enshrine Inari-shin as Yashiki-gami (family house god).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In addition, a small Shito shrine can be found on the roof of some buildings and department stores and in the precinct of some factories to enshrine Inari-shin as Yashiki-gami (family house god).
OK
